title: Notice of hearing in removal proceedings, immigration court
question: I was married for about 6 years. Had I-485 family based petition.Had first interview within a year from getting married.Never got temporary green card, due to FBI background check.Filed several serviced requests.My wife filed for devorce.At the same time we were called for the second intervie.Got note:"your case will have better result if you make an oppointement...".After 3mnths recived hearing note to my other-previous address which has been changed twice!!Looks like they didn't want me to recive it.What should I be ready for?Is it logit to doubt the marrage after 6 years?Can I seek help from US Senate?
question_tags: Immigration,Green cards,Deportation,Immigration court,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Federal crime,Form I-485 (adjustment of status),Federal court
answers:
The important question here is whether you are still married to your wife or divorced? If you are divorced your case is basicaly over since any petition filed on your behalf by your former spouse is automatically revoked if you never obtained your residence. if you are still married then you may still be eligible for residence, though there are many outstanding issues which need to be addressed.

You should consult with a qualified immigration attorney who can review the facts of your case and advise you as to any options that may be available to you.

Hello:

It has clearly been too long. At this point, you should consider filing a Writ of Mandate in Federal Court to force Immigration to make a decision. While it will not guarantee a 'Yes' decision, it will have the effect of moving the case forward. Please see below.

Regards,

Brian D. Lerner
Attorney at Law

Get a good lawyer first. If you marriage was entered in good faith (bona fide) and you can fight the case, you should get your greencard. Otherwise, you might have to wait for a long time even using the Senate to help.

Good Luck
